item.title: Final Fantasy 14: How To Get The Cactuar Minion
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Requirements To Unlock The Cactuar Minion In Final Fantasy 14
  • Complete 'Can't Do It Without U' In Final Fantasy 14
  • Complete 'Zombies Are People Too' In Final Fantasy 14

Final Fantasy 14 has many collectibles players can seek to obtain, from limited-time events such as the collaborations with other Final Fantasy titles, to the various mounts that can be unlocked. Minions are part of that too, and often take the form of cool items, monsters, or even the game's beloved characters.

Some of them also pay homage to iconic elements from the Final Fantasy franchise as a whole. That is the case with the Cactuar or Sabotender, the small cacti creatures known for their appearance, with stiff arms, legs, and a funny face, as well as for their signature move, 1000 Needles. In Final Fantasy 14 , one form that the evasive little creatures appear as is a minion players can unlock in game â€” here is how.

Requirements To Unlock The Cactuar Minion In Final Fantasy 14

The only requirements to get this minion are the player's level and progress in the Main Scenario Quests. It is necessary to complete the level 46 quest "The Black Wolf's Ultimatum" and reach level 47 to be able to complete the first quest needed to get the minion. Because there are no other requirements, there is no restriction for Free Trial players who want to obtain this minion.

Complete 'Can't Do It Without U' In Final Fantasy 14

The first quest players must complete to unlock the Cactuar Cutting is "Can't Do It Without U." This level 47 quest can be picked up inside the Waking Sands, in Vesper Bay. Throughout the MSQ, players will be rewarded with several Aetheryte Tickets to Vesper Baywhen asked to "Pray return to the Waking Sands," which can be used to arrive there faster. Otherwise, the nearest Aetheryte is in Horizon, in Western Thanalan.

Inside the Waking Sands, players must go to the room to the left and speak to Wigstan (X: 6.3, Y: 5.0), near Arenvald. He will explain what he wants to do and say he needs the strength of the U tribe, but they wouldn't listen to someone as weak as him. As a result, he asks the adventurer to go in his place and talk to the leader of the tribe â€” an NPC players have met before in the MSQ, located in Forgotten Springs.

There is an Aetheryte in Southern Thanalan that will leave the player directly in Forgotten Springs . Inside the round building nearby, talk to U'odh Nunh (X: 14.3, Y: 29.9), one of the members of the Company of Heroes you have met before. This will conclude the quest, and U'odh will tell the player they must prove themselves to the rest of the tribe â€” but this, and any subsequent quests he offers, can be ignored, as the only quest you need to complete involving him is "Can't Do It Without U."

Complete 'Zombies Are People Too' In Final Fantasy 14

Only after completing the first quest will the next one appear on the map. The next necessary quest is also level 47, and it's called "Zombies Are People Too." It can be found further to the south of the same area, as shown in the map above.

It can be started by speaking to Hab (X: 24.8, Y: 40.9), a sad zombie who will tell you about his loneliness and lament that his only friends, a group of Sabotenders, seem to have abandoned him. He will ask the player to look for his friends, saying the first one should be somewhere in the Black Shroud, the forest near Gridania.

The precise location for where to look will be indicated on the map, and the nearest Aetheryte to travel there will be in Bentbranch Meadows, in the Central Shroud . Exploring the area marked on the map, the player will find Sabotendrick (X: 17.5, Y: 22.4) on the upper portion of the map, on a cliff, as seen below:

Sabotendrick will flee when you speak to him, and after that, you will have to return to Hab. He will be in the same location where you first spoke to him, so teleporting to Forgotten Springs is the fastest way to get there. After talking to him again, he will speak of another friend, Sabotendred, who was lost in La Noscea , so that is where you will go next.

The closest Aetheryte to the next location is Camp Overlook in Outer La Noscea . Sabotendred (X: 15.9, Y: 9.8) will be under a cascade and will also flee once spoken to. This means it's time to return to Hab, once again found in the same place as before.

He will then speak of the last Sabotender friend the player must find for him, Sabotendale. This one is in Southern Thanalan , so the player will already be on the same map as he is. For those who don't want to ride or fly all the way to the middle of the map, the Aetheryte in Forgotten Springs will bring you closer to where you need to go.

Sabotendale can be found close to one of the game's beast tribes, the Amalj'aa, in Zanr'ak Encampment , but it can be really difficult to spot him. To get to him, players must reach the upper part of the camp, then approach the ledge at X: 17.6, Y: 24.0 . This will make the glowing objective visible on a small ledge below. Jumping there, the glowing pot will be reachable, but there will be no possible interaction with it â€” this is not a bug. All you need to do is use the quest's item, the Firesand Hab gave you, to target the pot and explode it, freeing Sabotendale.

After speaking to the creature, he will also flee. Return to Hab one last time so he can talk about what happened to the Sabotenders, and upon completing the quest, you will be rewarded with the Cactuar Cutting.

Remember the item will go into the inventory, and it is necessary to use it for the minion to be added to the collection .

item.title: Alien Rogue Incursion - First Gameplay Trailer
item.description: Alien Rogue Incursion looks like one of the scariest games that will be available on the PlayStation VR 2.

item.title: Silent Hill 2 Remake Shows Off Extended Gameplay Sequence
item.description:
Highlights

  • Konami unveils Silent Hill 2 remake gameplay with close ties to original, showcasing familiar scenes and slight gameplay changes.
  • Trailer reveals protagonist James' updated journey, new item locations, Unreal Engine 5 use, and detailed environments and creature designs.
  • Fans anticipate October release of Silent Hill 2 remake, hoping for a polished, playable game that lives up to the classic horror title's legacy.

Konami has finally unveiled more gameplay footage of the upcoming Silent Hill 2 remake, developed by Bloober Team. The reveal came during the Silent Hill Transmission that followed May's PlayStation State of Play.

The PlayStation State of Play offered a short teaser looking at Silent Hill 2 , particularly Angela's appearance. The teaser showed off scenes that follow the original game extremely closely, down to word-for-word conversation reproductions at points. However, the real look at gameplay wouldn't come until later.

Now, the Silent Hill 2 remake has unveiled some of the changes that are coming to the game alongside the title's gameplay. In the gameplay footage, protagonist James Sunderland is beginning his exploration of the town proper and heads inside a building by crawling through a whole, leading to him discovering the game's radio indoors instead of outside in an alley. He's still accosted by the same type of monster after picking up the radio, and pries off a wooden board from a nearby window to defend himself, instead of pulling one off a construction site.

After dispatching the monster, James returns to his search for Mary. Fans can get a good look at the environments here, as James picks up a couple of items pertinent to his search. He also takes out a notebook and marks down his progress at one point, another difference from the original game. After briefly meeting Laura, who promptly runs off, the footage skips ahead to James as he searches for Laura with Maria tagging along.

The Silent Hill 2 remake's use of Unreal Engine 5 is quite apparent as the two travel through Brookhaven Hospital, with the dim lighting catching on dust motes in the air. A creepy image of nurses in training with the faces scratched out alludes to the game's nurse enemies, which James encounters shortly thereafter. The gameplay teaser ends with James locked in a room and a creature descending from the ceiling that he'll have to deal with.

Will the Silent Hill 2 Remake Live Up to Expectations?

Many fans are waiting for the Silent Hill 2 remake's release with bated breath. The original title is considered a treasured classic among horror games to this day, despite its dated controls and graphics. It's a huge task to take on a game like this and not disappoint players. So far, the game's environments and creature designs look promising, and the facial animations are quite detailed. With the game's release coming in October, there's a lot that remains to be seen about the title. At the very least, the game looks far more polished and playable than the Silent Hill 2 HD remaster was on release.

item.title: Dynasty Warriors: Origins - Announcement Trailer
item.description: Dynasty Warriors: Origins revives the hack-and-slash action of the long-running ancient Chinese action series.

item.title: 13 Best 6-Player Co-Op Games, Ranked
item.description:
Highlights

  • Among Us is a universally popular game that anyone can play, making it a great choice for multiplayer gaming. With lobbies of up to 10 players, it's an engaging social deduction game that is best played with friends in a voice chat.
  • Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder's Revenge is a nostalgic beat-em-up game that appeals to fans of the retro TMNT games. With six playable characters and the option for six players, it's a fun throwback experience that captures the essence of the franchise.
  • Destiny 2 is a free-to-play FPS with RPG and MMO elements, perfect for a group of friends looking for cooperative gameplay. While some modes only support up to 3 players, larger groups can join up for modes like Raid and Menagerie for an epic multiplayer experience.

In the modern world of multiplayer gaming, there can never be enough players allowed to get together to play a game. From massively multiplayer games to more intimate lobbies with just friends, there are a lot of ways to experience games today alongside other people.

While three or four players might be a more common number to get playing together, there are a lot of games today that will support lobbies of a much larger size. It can be difficult to choose what type of game will be good for everybody to play together, but there are some marvelous options available that can include anybody, from veteran gamers to relative newcomers.

Updated on May 30, 2024, by Chris Harkin : With co-op still hugely prevalent at the top of the gaming industry, there is no better time to pick up some games that can accommodate a lot of friends at once. With new games always being released that are available for wide online multiplayer or more intimate, friend-filled sessions, gamers will never run out of great new options for titles to try out alongside a whole group of their gaming friends. While some co-op games don't provide for a group as large as six, there are plenty of popular games being released today and in the near future that provide for larger groups like this. With many options available, however, it can be hard for gamers to decide what 6-player title to dive into.

13 Pico Park

Metacritic Score: 7.1 (User Score)

Pico Park is one of the most unusual co-op games ever released. Supporting up to ten players in a single game, this puzzle title lets players work together as a larger group to try and find a key that will allow them to unlock the door at the end of the stage, permitting them to move on.

Pico Park comes with a huge variety of levels and game modes, making it a great party game for larger groups to play. The standard world mode comes with 48 different levels split into 12 different styles, while players can also play together locally or in battle/endless modes.

12 Human: Fall Flat

Metacritic Score: 70/100

One of the best party games for a group of gamers ever seen, Human: Fall Flat is a physics platformer that can be played by up to eight people online. It encourages players to work together to try and navigate puzzles and levels, many of which can be solved in a variety of different ways.

The fun in Human: Fall Flat is the completely ridiculous physics and the openness of the levels, allowing players to find their own solutions creatively. Working together in a larger group makes the game even more fun, making this a perfect single-evening experience for a party of six.

11 Killing Floor 2

Metacritic Score: 75/100

Another FPS game that is perfect for a group of six players, Killing Floor 2 , was released in 2016. Set in a world overtaken by military clones that have spread across Europe following the events of the first game, Killing Floor 2 allows up to six players to work together in the campaign against hordes of zombie-like creatures, making it one of the best co-op zombie games on the market.

Though there was some criticism leveled at the plot, the actual gameplay has been much praised, making Killing Floor 2 another perfect party game for a group of players looking to relax and turn off their brains. Players can work together to try and survive each mission or compete for the most kills and points.

10 Terraria

Metacritic Score: 81/100

Another game that allows a large group of players to enter a single world, Terraria has often been cited as having similarities to Minecraft but in two dimensions. There are a lot of things that make Terraria unique, though, including the intricacy of the crafting system.

This can be an overwhelming game to get into initially, but with a few friends along for the ride, Terraria is much easier to get to grips with quickly. As of version 1.4, up to 16 players can join a single server, making this a perfect cooperative experience with a lot of replayability for six players or more.

9 Minecraft

Metacritic Score: 82/100

One of the greatest games of all time, Minecraft , has proven its popularity many times over the last decade by retaining player numbers almost unheard of over a lengthy time. Minecraft offers gamers many ways to play, and a group of friends can come together in an online server or Java realm to do anything from creative builds to attempting to defeat the Ender Dragon together.

The wide range of capabilities available in Minecraft means that players can potentially keep engaging together in new projects endlessly. With such an active modding community and so many great multiplayer servers to try out, Minecraft is the ultimate party game for larger groups from six to ten or even smaller groups of friends.

8 Don't Starve Together

Metacritic Score: 83/100

A survival game with endless possibilities and a lot of stress to worry about, Don't Starve was infamous for being a challenge, but the sequel Don't Starve Together introduced co-op and made things even harder in some ways. This edition comes with a lot of survival meters to be kept track of, and even working together, players will find a lot of struggles.

Despite being one of the forerunners of the current survival genre's popularity, especially in co-op terms, Don't Starve Together is easy to learn but hard to master. Up to six gamers can play together, allowing for a hilarious and unique sort of evening.

7 The Forest

Metacritic Score: 83/100

The Forest is one of the best survival games for a larger group of friends to engage in. Up to 8 players can join a multiplayer session on the same island, making for a much better experience, as much of the building and crafting in The Forest becomes a lot easier alongside multiple friends.

The Forest is about a man whose plane crash lands on an island, forcing him to try to survive and try to fight off the native cannibals while searching for his son. The absolute chaos involved in entering cave systems and fighting off monstrous cannibal creatures is perfect for a larger group of friends. Horror survival games such as The Forest are perfect for groups of friends looking for a scary yet entertaining experience.

6 Among Us

Metacritic Score: 85/100

Among Us is a great and simplistic game that anybody can play. The popularity of Among Us is universal, given the social deduction style that has been so popular in board games for years. Whether or not players have ever played a video game before, they will be able to quickly catch on to the style of Among Us .

The lobbies support up to ten players, but playing online without friends in voice chat makes the game far less interesting. Six players or more can easily work together in their attempts to win the game and stop the impostors from murdering everybody.

5 Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredderâ€™s Revenge

Metacritic Score: 85/100

The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles classic arcade games made for some of the most memorable media in the franchise. Shredderâ€™s Revenge was a unique update to this beat-em-up series, released in 2022 for a variety of consoles and filled with the familiar kind of classic beat-em-up aspects that fans of the retro games will fall in love with all over again.

Even bringing back the 1987 animated TMNT series voice actors, this game is a true throwback and love letter to the origins of the franchise. The pixilated art style and fun gameplay have helped drive a slight resurgence of the beat-em-up genre, and with April Oâ€™Neil and Master Splinter being playable, six players can jump into this game without a problem.

4 Destiny 2

Metacritic Score: 85/100

If a few friends are looking for something free-to-play to jump into, Destiny 2 could be a great option. This online FPS game featuring RPG and MMO elements has become huge, with constant updates overhauling much of the gameplay to keep things changing, helping it become one of the best looter shooters of all time.

Despite some match types in Destiny 2 only featuring up to 3-player cooperation, up to six players are able to join together for modes such as Raid and the Menagerie. Either of these makes for a great option for a larger group of friends getting together, even working well for single players looking to meet a larger party for raids, as there are ways for a single extra to join as a fill for an already established party.

3 Stardew Valley

Metacritic Score: 89/100

One of the most relaxing games on the market, Stardew Valley , is a great way to chill out either alone or with a group of friends. While traditionally up to four players can join into a single co-op game, there are a variety of ways in which players can get more friends onto a single server.

Ever since Stardew was released on Beta nearly a decade ago, there have been ways to add more players to a server than what is supposedly allowed. This means that six-player games and even more are easily put together with the right know-how. This can be done through mods or even without them, making Stardew Valley a great option for a group of friends looking to chill out together.

2 Factorio

Metacritic Score: 90/100

One of the more complicated games available today, Factorio is a construction and management game that takes place in a 2D environment, where gamers are able to work together to create automated factories of varying complexity, continuing to get more complicated as time goes by.

To create the best possible version of this game, the developers kept it in early access for four years, but it was worth it to produce the incredible final version they did. Technically, though it would be difficult to get near this number, around 65,000 players can be on one server. For a group of six, however, Factorio is a must-try.

1 Forza Horizon 5

Metacritic Score: 92/100

A hugely loved racing game, Forza Horizon 5 , has added a lot of options over the years for players looking to relax, drive, or race across the country. One of the most major updates introduced cooperative play, allowing up to six players to work alongside each other in a convoy. Co-op even allows players to complete campaign missions alongside their friends.

While Forza Horizon 5 didn't start out as an amazing co-op adventure, it has evolved and has become even better through these additions, now offering chill and tense gaming experiences that can be played alone or with a whole group of friends.
